Musical events of the year '''1646 in [[music]]''':
== Events == *[[Luigi Rossi]] is invited to Paris by [[Cardinal Mazarin]].
== Classical music == *[[Giovanni Battista Granata]] – ''{{lang|it|Caprici armonici sopra la chittarriglia spagnuola...}}'', a collection of music for the treble guitar, published in [[Bologna]]. *[[Andreas Hammerschmidt]] – Part IV of the ''Musicalische Andachten''<ref>Snyder, Kerala J. (2007). {{Google books|qSXGOoambNcC|Dieterich Buxtehude: Organist in Lübeck}}. Boydell & Brewer. p. 18. {{ISBN|1-58046-253-7}}.</ref>

== Deaths == *[[September 11]] – [[Johann Stobäus]], composer (born 1580) *[[September 24]] – [[Duarte Lobo]], composer (born c. 1545) *[[October 3]] – [[Virgilio Mazzocchi]], Italian composer of sacred vocal music (born 1597) *''date unknown'' – [[Wojciech Dębołęcki]], writer and composer (born 1585) **[[Manuel Machado (composer)|Manuel Machado]], Portuguese harpist and composer of [[cantiga]]s and romances **[[Johann Vierdanck]], German composer, violinist and cornetist (buried 1 April) (b. 1605)

{{Infobox non-profit | name = AIGA |abbreviation = | image =Aiga logo.svg | caption =AIGA logo | map = | map_size = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | map_alt = <!-- map alt text --> | map_caption = | map2 = | type =Professional Association | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = --> | registration_id = | founded_date = {{start date|1914}} | founder = | predecessor = | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merged = | successor = | location =Headquarters in [[New York City]]<ref name="AIGA-about">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/About/|title=About AIGA|publisher=}}</ref> | addnl_location =73 chapters across the country<ref name="AIGA-chapters">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/chapters/|title=Find a chapter|publisher=}}</ref> | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people =Board President Dana Arnett<ref name="AIGA-board">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/board-of-directors/|title=AIGA board of directors|publisher=}}</ref> | area_served =[[United States]] | products = | services = | focus = | mission = | method = | revenue = | disbursed = | expenses = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = over 22,000<ref name="AIGA-about"/> | affiliations = | subsid = | languages =[[English language|English]] | owner = | motto = | formerly = | website = {{url|aiga.org}} | footnotes = }} '''The American Institute of Graphic Arts (AIGA)''' is a [[professional organization]] for [[design]].<ref name="AIGA-about"/><ref name="aiga_name_history">{{cite web | url = http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/about-name | title = AIGA name}}</ref> Its members practice all forms of [[communication design]], including [[graphic design]], [[typography]], [[interaction design]], branding and identity. The organization's aim is to be the standard bearer for professional ethics and practices for the design profession.<ref name="AIGA-about"/><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vupkAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA182&lpg=PA182&dq=aiga+history&source=bl&ots=RJmQFAlbAY&sig=XL7NVUPaZl9O2l4TDjF9NZWnyHI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi0uIra7ezPAhWoxYMKHf9lDao4MhDoAQg7MAY#v=onepage&q=aiga%20history&f=false|title=History of the Mass Media in the United States: An Encyclopedia|last=Blanchard|first=Margaret A.|date=2013-12-19|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135917425|language=en}}</ref> There are currently over 22,000 members and 73 chapters, and more than 200 student groups around the United States.{{fact|date=February 2017}}
==History== In 1911, [[Frederic Goudy]], [[Alfred Stieglitz]], and [[William Addison Dwiggins|W. A. Dwiggins]] came together to discuss the creation of an organization that was committed to individuals passionate about communication design.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://madmuseum.org/series/aiga|title=AIGA|website=madmuseum.org|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref> In 1913, president of the [[National Arts Club]], [[John G. Agar (lawyer)|John G. Agar]], announced the formation of The American Institute of Graphic Arts during the eighth annual exhibition of “The Books of the Year.” The National Arts Club was instrumental in the formation of AIGA in that they helped to form the committee to plan to organize the organization.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/11/13/104788833.html|title=ARTS CLUB WARNED OF 'THOUGHT TRUST'; While It Plans for Graphic Arts, Bacheller Also Warns of Our Europeanization. NEW THEMES FOR NOVELS Getting Away from Work, He Finds Butcher's Daughter Cultivates Only Ease and the Graces Now.|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> The committee formed included [[Charles DeKay]] and [[William Bailey Howland|William B. Howland]] and officially formed the American Institute of Graphic Arts in 1914.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aiga.org/How-Our-Quarter-Century-Began/|title=How Our Quarter Century Began|newspaper=AIGA {{!}} the professional association for design|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> Howland, publisher and editor of ''The Outlook'', was elected president.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Steven Heller|author2=Nathan Gluck|title=Seventy-five years of AIGA|url=http://www.aiga.org/about-history-75thanniversary/|website=aiga.org|accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> The goal of the group was to promote excellence in the graphic design profession through its network of local chapters throughout the country.<ref name=":0" />
In 1920, AIGA began awarding [[List of AIGA medalists|medals]] to "individuals who have set standards of excellence over a lifetime of work or have made individual contributions to innovation within the practice of design." Winners have been recognized for design, teaching, writing or leadership of the profession and may honor individuals posthumously.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aiga.org/medal|title=AIGA Medalists List|newspaper=AIGA {{!}} the professional association for design|access-date=2016-10-21}}</ref>
In 1982, the New York Chapter was formed and the organization began creating local chapters to decentralize leadership.<ref name=":1" />
Represented by Washington, D.C. arts advocate and attorney, James Lorin Silverberg, Esq., The Washington, D.C. Chapter of AIGA, was organized as the American Institute of Graphic Arts, Incorporated, Washington, D.C. on September 6, 1984.<ref>{{cite web|title=District of Columbia Corporate Records|url=http://corp.dcra.dc.gov/BizEntity.aspx/ViewEntityData?entityld=2787251|publisher=The District of Columbia}}</ref>
==Symbol sign project== {{main article|DOT pictograms}} The AIGA, in collaboration with the [[US Department of Transportation]], produced 50 standard symbols to be used on signs "in airports and other transportation hubs and at large international events". The first 34 symbols were published in 1974, receiving a [[Presidential Design Award]]. The remaining 16 designs were added in 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/symbol-signs|title=Symbol Signs|year=2009|publisher=AIGA|accessdate=September 2, 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091010215420/http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/symbol-signs| archivedate= October 10, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
== Annual competitions ==
===Cased=== In 2012, AIGA replaced all its competitions with a single competition called "Cased"<ref name="Cased-competition">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/cased/|title=Cased, AIGA's annual design competition|publisher=}}</ref> (formerly called "Justified"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/justified/#about |title=Justified: AIGA Annual Design Competition |author=AIGA |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref>). The stated aim of the competition is to demonstrate "the collective success and impact of the design profession by celebrating the best in contemporary design through case studies".<ref name="Cased-competition" />
===50 Books/50 Covers=== Between 1941 and 2011 AIGA sponsored a juried contest for the 50 best designed books published in the previous year, entitled "50 Books/50 Covers". Jurors included booksellers, book publishers, and designers such as [[George Salter]].<ref>''Fifty Books of the year 1963'', The American Institute of Graphic Arts, New York, 1964.</ref>
On February 17, 2012, AIGA announced that it would cease organizing the contest and that future contests would be organized by [[Design Observer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/AIGA-and-Design-Observer-partner-on-50-Books-50-Covers/ |title=AIGA and Design Observer Partner on "50 Books/50 Covers" |date=February 17, 2012 |author=AIGA |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref> This move has been criticized.<ref name=Unjustified>{{cite web |url=http://www.printmag.com/featured/aiga-unjustified/ |title=AIGA: Unjustified |first=Paula |last=Scher |authorlink=Paula Scher |work=[[Print (magazine)|Print Magazine]] |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref>
===365=== The 365 was an annual design competition for all graphic design other than book design.<ref name=Unjustified /> The last “365” competition was organized in 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/about-365/ |title=<nowiki>365 | Design Effectiveness Competition</nowiki> |author=AIGA |accessdate=June 3, 2014 }}</ref> after which it was replaced by the "Cased" competition.
==Conferences== AIGA organized two conferences, the AIGA Design Conference and GAIN: AIGA Design and Business Conference. Both conferences were held biennially and the two were held in alternating years. Beginning in 2016, the AIGA Design Conference will be held annually with the 2016 conference held in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://designconference.aiga.org/#!/|title=AIGA Design Conference|website=designconference.aiga.org|access-date=2016-08-14}}</ref>
===AIGA Design Conference===
The first AIGA Design Conference took place in Boston, Massachusetts in 1985.
Past AIGA Design Conferences include:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://designconference2009.aiga.org/timeline/|title="A Tradition Over Time". AIGA. Retrieved October 1, 2009.|publisher=|access-date=2009-10-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009041909/http://designconference2009.aiga.org/timeline/|archive-date=2009-10-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
*2017 - Minneapolis *2016 - Las Vegas *2015 - New Orleans *2013 - Minneapolis *2011 - Phoenix *2009 - Memphis *2007 - Denver *2005 - Boston *2003 - Vancouver *2001 - Washington *1999 - Las Vegas *1997 - New Orleans *1995 - Seattle *1993 - Miami *1991 - Chicago *1989 - San Antonio *1987 - San Francisco *1985 - Boston
The 2016 and 2017 conferences was hosted by [[Roman Mars]].<ref name="Design-conference-2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/AIGA-design-conference-2015/|title=Join us in New Orleans for the AIGA Design Conference|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aiga.org/board-of-directors/|title=AIGA board of directors|publisher=}}</ref>
==National board members== As of 2018, the national board consists of<ref name="AIGA-board"/> {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *Dana Arnett (President) *Terry Marks (Treasurer) *Justin Ahrens *Helen Armstorng *Ashleigh Axios *Antionette Carroll *Sarah Brooks *Sara Frisk *Karin Hibma *Rich Hollant *Randy J. Hunt *Jamie Myrold *Christine Taylor *Richard Ting *Hugh Weber *Gage Mitchell (Presidents council representative) {{div col end}}
== Affiliations == Between 2005 and 2009, AIGA was briefly a member of Icograda (now called [[Ico-D]]). In 2010, it withdrew from the international organization, citing financial reasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/why-has-aiga-withdrawn-from-icograda/ |title=Why has AIGA withdrawn from Icograda? |first=Richard |last=Grefe |date=January 25, 2010 |accessdate=July 15, 2014}}</ref>
== International membership == AIGA opened up membership beyond local chapters in 2014, benefiting creative professionals living and working outside of the USA.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
==Publications==
===Journals===
In 1947 AIGA started publishing the ''AIGA Journal of Graphic Design'' (ISSN 0736-5322),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/history-timeline/ |title=AIGA History Timeline |author=AIGA |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> which in 2000 was renamed ''Trace: AIGA Journal of Design'' (ISSN 1471-3497).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ipac.ocad.on.ca/ipac20/ipac.jsp?uri=link=3100006~!90266~!3100001~!3100002 |title=AIGA journal of graphic design / [Periodical] |website=OCAD U Library Catalogue |quote=Name changed to Trace: AIGA Journal of Design after v.18 no.2 (2000) |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> The journal ceased publication in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ipac.ocad.on.ca/ipac20/ipac.jsp?uri=link=3100006~!11624~!3100001~!3100002 |title=Trace / [Periodical] |quote=Subtitled: AIGA Journal of Design. Publication ceased as of April 2003. |website=OCAD U Library Catalogue |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}.</ref>
Between 2000 and 2003 AIGA published ''Loop: AIGA Journal of Interaction Design Education'', an “interactive, web-based” research journal on interaction and visual interface design co-sponsored by [[Virginia Commonwealth University]]’s Center for Design Studies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://loop1.aiga.org/content.cfm?alias=aboutloop |title=About Loop |publisher=AIGA |date=June 2013 |issue=7 |journal=Loop |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref>
Between 2004 and 2011 AIGA published ''Voice: AIGA Journal of Design'', “an online publication for the discussion of design matters” listing [[Steven Heller (graphic design)|Steven Heller]] as its editor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://voice.aiga.org/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040328225409/http://voice.aiga.org/ |archivedate=March 28, 2004 |title=Voice: AIGA Journal of Design |accessdate=July 18, 2014 |quote=Consulting Editor Steven Heller}}.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://voice.aiga.org/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515080542/http://voice.aiga.org/ |archivedate=May 15, 2011 |title=Voice: AIGA Journal of Design |accessdate=July 18, 2014 |quote=Editor Steven Heller}}.</ref> Although the journal was stated in “What AIGA is doing and why”<ref name="AIGA-what-why"/> and had been cited in scholarly research,<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Business Communication Quarterly |date=June 2008 |volume=71 |issue=2 |publisher=[[Sage Publications]] |pages=241–246 |title=Smiling With Customers |first=Clive |last=Muir |doi=10.1177/1080569908317320}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Urban Designscapes and the Production of Aesthetic Consent |journal=Urban Studies |first=Guy |last=Julier |volume=42 |issue=5/6 |date=May 2005 |pages=869–887 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.1080/00420980500107474}}</ref> after AIGA revamped its website in May 2011<ref name="AIGA-org">{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/faqs-about-aigaorg/ |title=FAQs: About aiga.org |author=AIGA |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> it was subsumed under AIGA’s main site and ceased to exist as a distinct entity.
===Books=== As part of its strategy to “publish critical thinking about design and designing”, AIGA also “copublishes selected works by thought leaders in design”<ref>{{cite book |title=Designing with Web Standards |edition=2nd |first=Jeffrey |last=Zeldman |publisher=New Riders |date=July 6, 2006 |isbn=0-321-38555-1 |page=xx}}</ref> under the imprint of “AIGA Design Press”.<ref name="AIGA-what-why">{{cite web |url=http://www.aiga.org/planning-for-aigas-future/#what-AIGA-is-doing-and-why |title=What AIGA is doing and why: 2011 |format=PDF |author=AIGA |page=35 |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> Published titles include * ''The Open Brand: When Push Comes to Pull in a Web-Made World'' (Kelly Mooney and Nita Rollins, 2008) * ''Digital Foundations: Intro to Media Design with the Adobe Creative Suite'' (Xtine Burrough and [[Michael Mandiberg]], 2008), which was released under a [[Creative Commons]] license<ref>{{cite web |url=https://creativecommons.org/tag/aiga-design-press |title=AIGA Design Press: Digital Foundations, CC-Licensed Media Design Instruction |first=Cameron |last=Parkins |date=December 22, 2008 |publisher=Creative Commons |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> * ''Designing for Interaction: Creating Smart Applications and Clever Devices'' (Dan Saffer, 2006) * ''Designing With Web Standards'' ([[Jeffrey Zeldman]], 2006) * ''Inside/Outside: From the Basics to the Practice of Design'' ([[Malcolm Grear]], 2006) * ''ZAG: The Number-One Strategy of High-Performance Brands'' ([[Marty Neumeier]], 2006) * ''Do Good: How Design Can Change the World'' (David B. Berman, 2008) * ''Writing for Visual Thinkers: A Guide for Artists and Designers'' (Andrea Marks, 2011)
AIGA has also published the periodically updated ''AIGA professional practices in graphic design''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n81-32755/ |title=American Institute of Graphic Arts |website=OCLC WorldCat Identities |publisher=[[OCLC]] |accessdate=July 18, 2014}}</ref> including a translation to simplified Chinese.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://china.staging.aiga.org/content.cfm/design-business-and-ethics_res |title=Design Business & Ethics, Chinese Edition |author=AIGA China |accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref>
===Other publication activities=== AIGA also maintains the AIGA Design Archives, which was identified as a publishing activity.<ref name="AIGA-what-why"/>
==See also== * [[List of AIGA medalists]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|www.aiga.org}}

{{other uses}} {{good article}} {{Infobox book | name = And the Band Played On: Politics, People and the AIDS Epidemic | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:And the Band Played On (first edition).jpg | caption = Cover of the first edition | author = [[Randy Shilts]] | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[HIV/AIDS]] | publisher = [[St. Martin's Press]] | release_date = 1987 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] and [[Paperback]]) | pages = 630 pp | isbn = 0-312-00994-1 | oclc = 16130075 }}
'''''And the Band Played On: Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic''''' is a 1987 book by ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' journalist [[Randy Shilts]]. The book chronicles the discovery and spread of the [[human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) and [[acquired immune deficiency syndrome]] (AIDS) with a special emphasis on government indifference and political infighting—specifically in the United States—to what was then perceived as a specifically [[gay]] disease. Shilts' premise is that AIDS was allowed to happen: while the disease is caused by a biological agent, incompetence and apathy toward those initially affected allowed its spread to become much worse.
The book is an extensive work of investigative journalism, written in the form of an encompassing time line; the events that shaped the [[epidemic]] are presented as sequential matter-of-fact summaries. Shilts describes the impact and the politics involved in battling the disease on particular individuals in the gay, medical, and political communities. Shilts begins his discussion in 1977 with the first confirmed case of AIDS, that of [[Grethe Rask]], a Danish doctor working in [[Africa]]. He ends with the announcement by actor [[Rock Hudson]] in 1985 that he was dying of AIDS, when international attention on the disease exploded.
''And the Band Played On'' was critically acclaimed and became a best-seller. Judith Eannarino of the ''[[Library Journal]]'' called it "one of the most important books of the year", upon its release.<ref name="eannarino">Eannarino, Judith (November 15, 1987). "And the Band Played On (book review)." ''Library Journal'' '''112''' (19) p. 71.</ref> It made Shilts both a star and a pariah for his coverage of the disease and the bitter politics in the gay community. He described his motivation to undertake the writing of the book in an interview after its release, saying, "Any good reporter could have done this story, but I think the reason I did it, and no one else did, is because I am gay. It was happening to people I cared about and loved."<ref name="geiger">{{cite news | first=H Jack | last=Geiger | title= Plenty of Blame to Go Around | date= 1987-11-08 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/08/books/plenty-of-blame-to-go-around.html | work =The New York Times Book Review | page = 9 | accessdate = 2007-12-27}}</ref> The book was later adapted into an [[And the Band Played On (film)|HBO film of the same name]] in 1993. Shilts was tested for HIV while he was writing the book; he died of complications from AIDS in 1994.
==Background== {{Quote box | width = 350px | align = right | quote = To me, that summed up the whole problem of dealing with AIDS in the media. Obviously, the reason I covered AIDS from the start was that...it was never something that happened to those other people. —[[Randy Shilts]] in 1983}}
Shilts decided to write ''And the Band Played On'' after attending an awards ceremony in 1983 where he was to receive a commendation for his coverage on AIDS. As described in the book, television announcer [[Bill Kurtis]] gave the keynote address and told a joke: "What's the hardest part about having AIDS? Trying to convince your wife that you're [[Haiti]]an."<ref>p. 384, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Shilts responded to the joke by saying that it "says everything about how the media had dealt with AIDS. Bill Kurtis felt that he could go in front of a journalists' group in San Francisco and make AIDS jokes. First of all, he could assume that nobody there would be gay and, if they were gay, they wouldn't talk about it and that nobody would take offense at that. To me, that summed up the whole problem of dealing with AIDS in the media. Obviously, the reason I covered AIDS from the start was that, to me, it was never something that happened to those other people."<ref name="geiger"/>
After publication of the book, Shilts explained his use of the title: "''And the Band Played On'' is simply a snappier way of saying 'business as usual'. Everyone responded with an ordinary pace to an extraordinary situation."<ref name="engel">Engel, Margaret. "AIDS and Prejudice: One Reporter's Account of the Nation's Response." ''The Washington Post'', December 1, 1987, p. Z10.</ref> The phrase itself is originally from [[The Temptations]]' popular 1970 song about encroaching chaos, ''[[Ball of Confusion (That's What the World Is Today)]]''; in the song, the phrase repeatedly signals that no one is paying proper attention to world problems.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://genius.com/The-temptations-ball-of-confusion-thats-what-the-world-is-today-lyrics|title=Ball of Confusion (That's What the World Is Today) (lyrics by Norman Whitfield and Barrett Strong|website=Genius.com|date=2 April 2017|}}</ref>
==Summary== Shilts focuses on several organizations and communities that were either hit hardest by AIDS—and were given the task of finding the cause of the disease—or begging the government for money to fund research and provide social services to people who were dying. He often uses an [[Third-person omniscient narrative|omniscient point of view]] to portray individuals' thoughts and feelings.
===Gay community=== AIDS in the United States first struck gay men and [[intravenous drug use (recreational)|IV drug users]] in Los Angeles, New York City, and San Francisco due to unsafe sexual and drug-taking practices. Shilts' sources in the gay community tried to remember the last time everyone they knew was healthy, which was the [[United States Bicentennial]] celebration in 1976, when sailors came from all over the world to New York.<ref>pp. 142–143 ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Some of them carried [[sexually transmitted disease]]s and rare tropical fevers. A marked difference in these cities arose in two phases of consciousness in the gay community: "Before" in 1980, and "After" by 1985. "Before", according to Shilts, was characterized by a care-free innocence, preceding the period when gay men were aware of a deadly infectious disease.<ref>p. 12, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> "After" signified the realization that gay men knew most or all of their friends were infected with AIDS, and the syndrome became pervasive throughout the media.<ref>pp. 585–590, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
In San Francisco, particularly in the Castro District, gay community activists such as [[Bill Kraus]] and [[Cleve Jones]] found a new direction in gay rights when so many men came down with strange illnesses in 1980. The San Francisco Department of Public Health began tracing the disease, linked it to certain sexual practices, and made recommendations—stop having sex—to gay men to avoid getting sick, a directive that defied the chief reason why many gay men had migrated to the Castro, and for what gay rights activists in San Francisco had fought for years.<ref>pp. 38–40, 154–155 ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Kraus and Jones often found themselves fighting a two-fronted battle: against city politicians who would rather not deal with a disease that affected gay men, who were seen as an undesirable population, and the gay men themselves, who refused to listen to doomsday projections and continued their unsafe behavior.<ref>pp. 152–154, 167, 180, 200, 209–210, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
In New York City, men like [[Larry Kramer]] and [[Paul Popham]], who had previously shown no desire for leadership, were forced by bureaucratic apathy into forming the [[Gay Men's Health Crisis]] to raise money for medical research and to provide social services for scores of gay men who began getting sick with [[opportunistic infections]].<ref>p. 133–134, 166–167, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Shilts describes the desperate actions of the group to get recognition by Mayor [[Ed Koch]] and assistance from the city's Public Health Department to provide social services and [[sex education|preventive education]] about AIDS and [[unsafe sex]].<ref>pp. 309–311, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
In these cities, however, the sizable gay communities in most instances were responsible for raising the most money for research, providing the money for and subsequently the social services for the dying, and educating themselves and other high-risk groups. Kramer would go on to form [[ACT UP|AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power]] (ACT-UP), a political activist organization that forced government and media to pay attention to AIDS.<ref>"Larry Kramer." Contemporary Authors Online, Gale, 2009. Reproduced in [http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/BioRC Biography Resource Center]. Farmington Hills, Mich.: Gale, 2009.</ref> Jones formed the [[NAMES Project]] that created the AIDS Memorial Quilt, the largest folk art display in the world.<ref>"Cleve Jones." Gay & Lesbian Biography. St. James Press, 1997. Reproduced in [http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/BioRC Biography Resource Center]. Farmington Hills, Mich.: Gale, 2009.</ref>
===Medical community=== Doctors were the first to deal with the toll that AIDS would take in the United States. Some—like [[Marcus Conant]], James Curran, [[Arye Rubenstein]], [[Michael S. Gottlieb]], and [[Mathilde Krim]]—would also realize their professional life's courses in dealing with patient after patient who showed up in their offices with baffling illnesses, most notably [[lymphadenopathy]], [[pneumocystis carinii pneumonia]], [[Kaposi's Sarcoma]], [[toxoplasmosis]], [[cytomegalovirus]], [[cryptosporidia]], and other opportunistic infections that caused death by a grisly combination of ailments overtaxing a compromised [[immune system]]. With no information on how the disease was spread, hospital staff were often reluctant to handle AIDS patients, and Shilts reported that some medical personnel refused to treat them at all.<ref>pp. 150, 321–322, 374–375 ''And the Band Played On''.</ref>
Shilts praised the Public Health Department of San Francisco's handling of the new communicable disease as they tracked down people who were sick and linked them to other people who had symptoms, although some of them were living in different parts of the country. He criticized the New York City Public Health Department for doing very little, specifically when Public Health Director [[David Sencer]] refused to call AIDS an emergency and stated that the Public Health Department need not do anything because the gay community was handling it sufficiently.<ref>p. 310, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
Around the same time gay men were getting sick in the United States, doctors in Paris were receiving patients who were African or who had lived in Africa with the same symptoms as the Americans. Parisian researchers Jean-Claude Chermann, [[Françoise Barré-Sinoussi|Françoise Barre]], [[Luc Montagnier]], and doctor [[Willy Rozenbaum]] began taking biopsies of HIV-infected [[lymph nodes]] and discovered a new [[retrovirus]].<ref>pp. 219, 229, 237–238, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> As a scientific necessity to compare it to the American version of HIV, French doctors representing the [[Pasteur Institute]] sent a colleague to the [[National Cancer Institute]], where [[Robert Gallo]] was also working on the virus. The colleague switched the samples, Shilts reported, because of a grudge he had against the Pasteur Institute.<ref>pp. 238, 239–240, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Instead of Gallo comparing his samples with the French samples, he found the very same retrovirus as the French sample, putting back any new results in AIDS research for at least a year.<ref>pp. 264, 386–388, 401, 409, 418–420 ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
Departmental ego and pride, according to Shilts, also confounded research as the [[Centers for Disease Control]] and the [[National Cancer Institute]]s battled over funding and who might get credit for medical discoveries that were to come from the isolation of HIV, blood tests to find HIV, or any possible [[vaccine]].<ref>pp. 429–430, 434–435, 444–445, 447–448, 450–452, 460–462, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Once AIDS became known as a "gay disease" there was particular difficulty for many doctors in different specialties to get other medical professionals to acknowledge that AIDS could be transmitted to people who were not gay, such as infants born from drug-using mothers,<ref>pp. 103–104, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> children and adults who had [[hemophilia]] (and later, their wives),<ref>pp.115–116, 160–161, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> [[Haiti]]ans,<ref>pp. 124, 135–136, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> and people who had received [[blood transfusions]].
The discovery of AIDS in the nation's blood supply and subsequent lack of response by [[blood bank]] leadership occurred as early as 1982,<ref>pp. 195, 220–223, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> yet it was not until 1985, when AIDS antibody testing was approved by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA), that blood bank industry leaders acknowledged that HIV could be transmitted through blood transfusions.<ref>pp. 307–309, 332–333, 344–346, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> Shilts' coverage revealed the feeling among blood bank industry leaders that screening donors for [[hepatitis]] alone might offend the donors, and that the cost of screening all the blood donations provided across the country every year was too high to be feasible.<ref>p. 223, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
===Political and governmental agencies=== The Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the agency responsible for tracking down and reporting all communicable diseases in the U.S., faced governmental apathy in the face of mounting crisis. Shilts reported how CDC epidemiologists forged ahead blindly after being denied funding for researching the disease repeatedly. Shilts expressed particular frustration describing instances of the CDC fighting with itself over how much time and attention was being paid to AIDS issues.<ref>pp.292–293, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
Although Reagan Administration officials like [[Health and Human Services]] Secretary [[Margaret Heckler]] and Assistant Secretary [[Edward Brandt]] spoke publicly about the epidemic, calling it in 1983 its "Number One Health Priority" no extra funding was given to the Centers for Disease Control or the National Institutes of Health for research.<ref>pp. 293–4 ''And the Band Played On''</ref> What the U.S. Congress pushed through was highly politicized and embattled, and a fraction of what was spent on similar public health problems.<ref>pp. 294–298, 363–364, 455–456, 471–472, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
Shilts made comparisons to the government's disparate reaction to the [[Chicago Tylenol murders]], and the recent emergence of [[Legionnaire's Disease]] in 1977. In October 1982, seven people died after ingesting [[cyanide]]-laced [[Tylenol (brand)|Tylenol]] capsules. The ''New York Times'' wrote a front-page story about the Tylenol scare every day in October, and produced 33 more stories about the issue after that. More than 100 law enforcement agents, and 1,100 [[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|Food and Drug Administration]] employees worked on the case. [[Johnson & Johnson]] disclosed they spent $100 million attempting to uncover who had tampered with the bottles. In October 1982, 634 people were reported having AIDS, and of those, 260 had died. The ''New York Times'' wrote three stories in 1981 and three more stories in 1982 about AIDS, none on the front page.<ref>p. 191 ''And the Band Played On''.</ref> The Tylenol Crisis was a criminal act of product-tampering; Legionnaire's Disease was a public health emergency. Twenty-nine members of the [[American Legion]] died in 1976 at a convention in [[Philadelphia]]. The [[National Institute of Health]] spent $34,841 per death of Legionnaire's Disease. In contrast, the NIH spent $3,225 in 1981 and about $8,991 in 1982 for each person who died of AIDS.<ref>p. 186 And the Band Played On.</ref>
Shilts accused Ronald Reagan of neglecting to address AIDS to the American people until 1987—calling his behavior "ritualistic silence"—even after Reagan called friend Rock Hudson to tell him to get well.<ref>p. 588, ''And the Band Played On''.</ref> After Hudson's death and in the face of increasing public anxiety, Reagan directed [[Surgeon General of the United States|Surgeon General]] [[C. Everett Koop]] to provide a report on the epidemic. Though Koop was a political conservative, his report was nevertheless clear about what causes AIDS and what people and the U.S. government should do to stop it, including sex and AIDS education provided for all people.<ref>587–598, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
On a civic level, the closure of [[gay bathhouse]]s in San Francisco became a bitter political fight in the gay community. Activists put pressure on the San Francisco Public Health director to educate people about how AIDS is transmitted, and demanded he close bathhouses as a matter of public health.<ref>pp. 153–154, 305–307, 314–317, 413–418, 436–439, 440–443, 481–482, ''And the Band Played On''</ref>
===News media=== Shilts was assigned to AIDS full-time at ''The San Francisco Chronicle'' in 1982. It was from this unique vantage point that he repeatedly criticized the U.S. [[news media]] for ignoring the medical crisis because it did not affect people who mattered, only gays and drug addicts.<!-- <ref name='Story in Closet'>Shilts, Randy (August 3, 1985). [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/06/04/MNAIDS04SHILTS1.DTL&hw=The+Story+in+the+Closet&sn=001&sc=1000 "The Story in the Closet"] ''San Francisco Chronicle'' p. 36</ref>--> Shilts noted most newspapers would print stories about AIDS only when it affected heterosexuals, sometimes taking particular interest in stories about AIDS in [[prostitutes]]. AIDS was not reported in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' until it involved heterosexuals.<ref>p. 137, ''And the Band Played On''.</ref> Many stories called AIDS a "gay plague" or "homosexual disease" in articles that pointed to it showing up in new populations, like [[hemophiliacs]] or people who had received blood transfusions.<ref>pp. 353–354, ''And the Band Played On''.</ref> Shilts recounted the irony of a reporter commenting on how little was reported about the disease, then linking it once more to rarer instances of transmission to non-drug-using heterosexuals.<ref>pp. 110, 183, 213, 267–268, 320 ''And the Band Played On''.</ref> On the other end of the extreme, a general [[phobia]] of AIDS was exacerbated by the news media who erroneously reported that AIDS could be contracted by household contact, without checking any facts in their stories, which prompted mass hysteria across the United States.<ref>pp. 299–301, 320–321, ''And the Band Played On''.</ref>
==Critical reception== The book became a commercial success, contrary to Shilts' own expectations.<ref name="grimes"/> It remained on the ''[[New York Times Bestseller List]]'' for five weeks, was translated into seven languages, nominated for a [[National Book Award]], and made Shilts an "AIDS celebrity".<ref name="grimes">Grimes, William (February 18, 1994). [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/18/obituaries/randy-shilts-author-dies-at-42-one-of-first-to-write-about-aids.html "Randy Shilts, Author, Dies at 42; One of First to Write About AIDS"] ''The New York Times'', p. D.17.</ref> In ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', Shilts is compared to great American writers whose careers were made by the circumstances surrounding them, such as [[Thomas Paine]] in the [[American Revolution]], [[Edward R. Murrow]] during [[the Blitz]], and [[David Halberstam]] during the [[Vietnam War]]. Writer Jon Katz explains, "No other mainstream journalist has sounded the alarm so frantically, caught the dimensions of the AIDS tragedy so poignantly or focused so much attention on government delay, the nitpickings of research funding and institutional intrigue".<ref name="katz">Katz, Jon (May 27, 1993). "AIDS and the Media: Shifting Out of Neutral", ''Rolling Stone'', Issue 657, pp. 31–32.</ref> In the ''[[American Journal of Public Health]]'', Howard Merkel characterizes ''And the Band Played On'' as the first volume of the [[historiography]] of AIDS.<ref name="merkel">Merkel, Howard (July 2001). "Journals of the Plague Years: Documenting the History of the AIDS Epidemic in the United States", ''American Journal of Public Health'', '''91''' (7), p. 1025.</ref> Because the content expanded into law and science, reviews were published not only in literary sources but legal and medical journals as well.
===Literary=== Literary reviews of the work were generally positive, with reviewers commenting on the "hypnotic" and "thriller-like" qualities of the book. Shilts' investigative and journalistic endeavors were praised, and reviewers seemed genuinely moved by the personal stories of the major players.<ref group=note>Judith Eannarino noted, "Shilts has the ability to draw the reader hypnotically into the personal lives of his characters. That, and his monumental investigative effort, would have made this a best-selling novel—if the contents weren't so horribly true."(Eannarino, Judith (November 15, 1987). "And the Band Played On (book review)." ''Library Journal'' '''112''' (19) p. 71.) A reviewer with the feminist magazine ''Hera'' agreed, saying, "''And the Band Played On'' reads like a mystery thriller. The fact that it is non-fiction adds to the intensity but also increases the rage the reader is left with."(Johnston, Peg. "And The Band Played On: Politics, People and the AIDS Epidemic; A Review of the book by Randy Shilts." ''Hera''. March 31, 1989. '''9''' (2), p. 3.) Elena Brunet in ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' called it "An important, masterful piece of investigative reporting".(Brunet, Elena. "And the Band Played On: Politics, People and the AIDS Epidemic by Randy Shilts." ''Los Angeles Times'': October 2, 1988. p. 14.) Anthony Clare in ''[[The Times]]'' stated in a review, "''And the Band Played On'' is a formidable chronicle of wasted time, petty intrigue, bigoted posturing, blind faith and suffering", before warning the United Kingdom their response to AIDS was drawing too close a parallel to the United States'.(Clare, Anthony. "Chronicle of many deaths foretold: Review of 'And The Band Played On' by Randy Shilts", ''The Times'', February 28, 1988.) Joan Breckenridge in ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' gave the book high praise for "an excellent piece of both investigative and political journalism", and for the style of writing, although cautioning that at more than 600 pages casual readers might be overwhelmed.(Breckenridge, Joan. "The awful epidemic that was allowed to happen: And the Band Played On: Politics, People and the AIDS Epidemic." ''The Globe and Mail (Canada)'', December 5, 1987.) Nan Goldberg in ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' characterized it as a, "groundbreaking book on the history of the AIDS epidemic...every element of a thriller." (Goldeberg, Nan. "''Science Big Shot: Passion, Politics, and the Struggle for an AIDS Vaccine'' (book review)." ''The Boston Globe'', January 6, 2002.)</ref> ''And the Band Played On'' won the [[Stonewall Book Award]] for 1988.<ref>American Library Association. {{cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/ala/glbtrt/stonewall/stonewallbook.htm |title=The Stonewall Book Award website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070407193541/http://www.ala.org/ala/glbtrt/stonewall/stonewallbook.htm |archivedate=2007-04-07 }} Retrieved on December 21, 2007</ref> It earned the 10th spot on "100 Lesbian and Gay Books That Changed Our Lives", compiled by the ''Lambda Book Report''.<ref>Monteagudo, Jesse. "100 lesbian and gay books that changed our lives." '' Lambda Book Report''; January 2000. Vol. 8, Iss. 6; p. 12, 2 pgs.</ref> In 1999, The [[New York City Public Library]] topped its list of "21 New Classics for the 21st Century" with ''And the Band Played On''.<ref>Rogers, Michael. "NY Librarians Pick 21 New Classics." ''Library Journal'', 10/01/99, Vol. 124 Issue 16, p18, 2p</ref> Two years after it was published however, Shilts remained "fundamentally disappointed" when a radical response to the AIDS crisis did not materialize, despite the reaction to his book.<ref>Marcus, p. 326.</ref>
In a 1988 book review, Jack Geiger of ''[[The New York Times]]'' commented that the detail in Shilts' work was too confusing, being told "in five simultaneous but disjointed chronologies, making them all less coherent", and notes that Shilts neglected to dedicate as much detail to black and Hispanic intravenous drug users, their partners and their children as to gay men. Geiger also expressed doubts that a swifter response by the government would have stemmed the spread of AIDS as quickly as Shilts was implying.<ref name="geiger"/> Woodrow Myers from the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was frustrated by Shilts not asking the right questions: "Shilts fails to probe the broader questions and stops where far too many of us stop: We don't ask why the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] and the entitlements like [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]] are getting all the money when the homosexuals and the IV drug abusers with AIDS and the [[multiple sclerosis]] patients are not."<ref>Myers, Woodrow. "AIDS: A Reporter's Journey Into the Maelstrom AND THE BAND PLAYED ON by Randy Shilts." ''Los Angeles Times''. Los Angeles, California: December 6, 1987. p. 6.</ref> The ''Gay Community News'' in [[Boston]] also criticized the book's implications that a diagnosis of HIV indicated that death was sure and imminent.<ref>Kyper, John. "Stories from the epidemic: Two important books about the impact of AIDS." ''Gay Community News''. Boston: September 21, 1991. Vol. 19, Iss. 9; p. 8.</ref> Richard Rouilard, editor of ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'' in 1992 criticized Shilts for being out of touch with the contemporary style of activism and its sexual overtones.<ref>Shaw, David. "Gay Journalists Hold First Conference Media: Delegates assess progress being made against newsroom hostility and the battles that remain." ''Los Angeles Times'': June 28, 1992. p. 14</ref>
===Science and law=== Shilts' book has been used as a standard by the lay press when reviewing books chronicling subsequent medical crises including [[breast cancer]],<ref>Bolotin, Susan. "Slash, Burn and Poison (book review).'' The New York Times'', April 13, 1997, Sunday, Section 7; Page 8</ref> [[chronic fatigue syndrome]],<ref>"A Chronic Fatigue Cover-Up?" ''Newsweek'', April 22, 1996, p. 62.</ref> [[Agent Orange]],<ref>Solomon, Charles. "Waiting for an Army to Die: The Tragedy of Agent Orange by Fred A. Wilcox." ''Los Angeles Times'': December 17, 1989. p. 10</ref> and continued response to AIDS.<ref>Biemiller, Lawrence. "Book World; A Clinical Look at Life With AIDS." ''The Washington Post'': April 2, 1993. p. D.02</ref><ref>Randal, Judith. "Reality Check; Fighting AIDS in the Trenches." ''The Washington Post'': February 9, 1993. p. Z.19.</ref> However, the academic and scientific communities have been somewhat more critical. Howard Merkel, in the ''American Journal of Public Health'', notes Shilts' tendency to assign blame, writing "A requirement of the journalist, and certainly the historian, however, is to explain human society rather than to point fingers".<ref name="merkel"/> Jon Katz in ''Rolling Stone'' refutes this by stating "[Shilts] fused strong belief with the gathering of factual information and the marshaling of arguments, the way the founders of the modern press did. In doing so, he has exposed the notion of objectivity as bankrupt, ineffective, even lethal".<ref name="katz"/>
Although Sandra Panem in the journal ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' praised Shilts' efforts and the attention the book brought to AIDS, she criticized his simplistic interpretation of science and the ways research is fostered and accomplished in the U.S. Panem furthermore believes Shilts gives appropriate weight to the issue of [[homophobia]] hampering attention on the disease, but remarks that even if AIDS had struck a more socially acceptable group of people, similar delays and confusion would have slowed medical progress.<ref name="panem">Panem, Sandra (February 26, 1988). "Review: A Drama and Questions", ''Science'' '''239''' (4843), pp. 1039–1040.</ref>
Wendy Parmet, a professor at [[Northeastern University Law School]], highlights the greatest strengths of ''And the Band Played On'' to be "the pain and courage of individual confronted with AIDS" and how it "eloquently portrays the human side of the crisis" and believes the blame others criticized to be justified; but Parmet considers his technique of assigning an omniscient point of view a weakness, suggesting that it blurs the lines between fact and fiction.<ref>Parmet, Wendy (1986). "AIDS and the Law/And the Band Played on (Book)", ''[[American Journal of Law & Medicine]]'', '''12''' (3/4), p. 503–510.</ref> In ''[[Contemporary Sociology]]'', Peter Manning and Terry Stein also call Shilts' narrative method into question, and ask why, for a syndrome that affects people beyond race, class, and sexual orientation, that Shilts focuses so narrowly on AIDS as it is related to homosexuality. The writers, however, were mostly impressed with the book, calling it an "informative, often brilliant, overview of the emergent meanings of the AIDS epidemic".<ref>Manning, Peter and Stein, Terry (May 1989). "On the Social Meanings of AIDS", Contemporary Sociology '''18''' (3), p. 422–424.</ref>
Shilts is often quoted as claiming that Ronald Reagan neglected to mention AIDS publicly until 1987. However, Reagan briefly mentioned AIDS research in questions and answers during a news conference on September 17, 1985.<ref>{{cite web |year=1985 |url=http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1985/91785c.htm |title=The President's News Conference: September 17, 1985, Federal Support for AIDS Research |publisher=www.reagan.utexas.edu/ |accessdate=2009-01-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090221094807/http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1985/91785c.htm| archivedate= 21 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Gaëtan Dugas as "Patient Zero"=== The book includes extensive discussion of [[Gaëtan Dugas]], a Canadian flight attendant who died in 1984.<ref name="lrb"/> Dugas was labeled [[Index case|Patient Zero]] of AIDS, because he was linked directly or indirectly with 40 of the first 248 reported cases of AIDS in the United States, and after he was told of his ability to infect others, defiantly continued to have unprotected sex. Many book reviews concentrated their material on Dugas, or led their assessment of the book with discussion of his behavior. Some reviewers interpreted Shilts' naming Dugas "Patient Zero" to mean that Dugas brought AIDS to North America; the ''[[National Review]]'' called Dugas the "Columbus of AIDS" and in their review of ''And the Band Played On'' states, "[Dugas] picked up the disease in Europe through sexual contact with Africans. Traveling on his airline-employee privileges, he spread it here from coast to coast."<ref>"The Columbus of AIDS", ''The National Review'' (November 6, 1987), p. 19.</ref> Shilts never stated this in the book, instead writing, "Whether Gaëtan Dugas actually was the person who brought AIDS to North America remains a question of debate and is ultimately unanswerable ... there's no doubt that Gaëtan played a key role in spreading the new virus from one end of the United States to the other."<ref>p. 439, ''And the Band Played On''</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' titled its review of ''And the Band Played On'' "The Appalling Saga of Patient Zero", erroneously restating the claim that Dugas had brought AIDS to the continent.<ref>Henry III, William A. (October 19, 1987). "[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,965791,00.html The Appalling Saga of Patient Zero]", ''Time''. Retrieved on May 8, 2009.</ref> Even a press release by St. Martin's Press made the connection between Dugas and the introduction of AIDS to the Western World in its title, but not its text.<ref name="crimp">Crimp, Douglas (Winter, 1987). "How to Have Promiscuity in an Epidemic." ''AIDS: Cultural Analysis/Cultural Activism'' '''43''' pp. 237–271</ref>
When the book was released, Dugas' story became a controversial subject in the Canadian media. Shilts claimed that "the Canadian press went crazy over the story" and that "Canadians... saw it as an offense to their nationhood."<ref name="engel"/> The original study identifying Dugas as the index case had been completed by [[William Darrow]], but it was called into question by [[University of California San Francisco]] epidemiologist Andrew Moss. Moss wrote in a letter to the editor of ''The New York Review of Books'', "There is very little evidence that Gaetan was 'patient zero' for the US or for California," while also stating that Shilts did not overstress Dugas' lack of personal responsibility.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Moss AR |year=1988 |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/4227 |title= 'AIDS without end' |journal= New York Review of Books |volume=35 |issue=19 |accessdate=2008-08-24}}</ref> Sandra Panem in ''Science'' uses Shilts' approach toward Dugas' behavior as an example of his "glib" treatment of the science involved in the epidemic.<ref name="panem"/> Author [[Douglas Crimp]] suggests that Shilts' representation of Dugas as "murderously irresponsible" is in actuality "Shilts' homophobic nightmare of himself", and that Dugas is offered as a "scapegoat for his heterosexual colleagues, in order to prove that [Shilts], like them, is horrified by such creatures."<ref name="crimp"/> Many years later, in the 2000s, it was shown, by tracing the roots of the virus, that it had spread from Africa to Haiti, and then to the U.S. in the mid 1960s, before Dugas would have been very sexually active, if at all, and before he was working as a flight attendant.<ref name=patzer>[http://www.radiolab.org/story/169885-aids/ The Cell That Started a Pandemic], ''Radiolab.org'', with guests and research from: [[Nathan Wolf]] author of ''[[The Viral Storm]]''; [[Carl Zimmer]], author of ''[[A Planet of Viruses]]''; [[Michael Worobey]], [[MicrobeWorld.org]]'s "Meet the Scientist Podcast"; [[David Quammen]], author of ''[[Spillover: Animal Infections and the Next Human Pandemic|Spillover]]''; [[Beatrice H. Hahn]] of [[Penn Center for AIDS Research]].</ref> Even the labelling of Dugas as "Patient Zero" was due to an misunderstanding of the study of sexual contacts amongst a group of men indicating how the disease was transmitted – he was identified in the study as ‘Patient [letter] O’, for "Out of California" – but people reading and discussing the research began referring to and thinking about a "Patient Zero" as the origin of the disease.<ref name="lrb">{{cite news |last1=Crewe |first1=Tom |title=Here was a plague |url=https://www.lrb.co.uk/v40/n18/tom-crewe/here-was-a-plague |accessdate=29 September 2018 |publisher=London Review of Books |date=27 September 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, a study of early AIDS cases demonstrated that Dugas could not have been "Patient Zero".<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nature19827.epdf?ttreferrer_access_token=z0xXoLXHonkirkD_hU1jk9RgN0jAjWel9jnR3ZoTv0Mz5UkminhxQD8O3RqOtslw0uWnC8Yne3mUv32VmwjGPypGuqJT0TZeiLtsZb49IGRJf6V-wefqs5PWP2Zmz2neUNsKL8cH6Lgl4duhbwVFyGFyS_SpnROTz0ii2YbTD4zpYNY1EMUO0FYZn3LyRxi7Fe0SDLem4hpc01XbTdxF3DGYFAjTFX9jLdruf-bmalV8a5l6t-H_6eyTj_nm19jRIZfwaNR5Mx_RBGKhkHJUzg_Q5pw84M70ucJLf_WneW0=&tracking_referrer=www.theguardian.com|title=1970s and ‘Patient 0’ HIV-1 genomes illuminate early HIV/AIDS history in North America|first1=Michael|last1=Worobey|first2=Thomas D.|last2=Watts|first3=Richard A.|last3=McKay|first4=Marc A.|last4=Suchard|first5=Timothy|last5=Granade|first6=Dirk E.|last6=Teuwen|first7=Beryl A.|last7=Koblin|first8=Walid|last8=Heneine|first9=Philippe|last9=Lemey|first10=Harold W.|last10=Jaffe|date=26 October 2016|publisher=|journal=Nature|volume=539|issue=7627|pages=98–101|accessdate=23 July 2018|doi=10.1038/nature19827|pmc=5257289}}</ref>
==After publication== While Shilts was writing the book he was tested for HIV but insisted his doctor not tell him the results until the book was finished so it would not affect his journalistic integrity and judgment.<ref>Levine, Bettijane (February 17, 1993). "Shilts Confirms He Is HIV-Positive", ''Los Angeles Times'', p. 1.</ref><ref name="lrb"/> On the day he sent the final manuscript to the publisher, he learned he was HIV-positive. He also revealed that he received abuse from gays for the articles he wrote for the ''San Francisco Chronicle'' supporting the bathhouse closures, as well as for ''And the Band Played On'', saying it was common for him to be spat upon in the Castro District.<ref>Kirka, Danica. "Randy Shilts Fighting Against the Rules Restricting Gays in the Military;" ''Los Angeles Times'': July 25, 1993. p. 3</ref> He was openly booed when he attended the premiere of ''[[The Times of Harvey Milk]]''—based on his book ''The Mayor of Castro Street''—at the [[Castro Theatre]]. Footage he had shot as a television reporter was included in the film, but during the construction of the documentary he was so controversial that the film's editors removed him from footage showing him with Milk.<ref>Marcus, p. 270.</ref> Following the publication of ''And the Band Played On'', however, he was "worshipped" by many in the gay community for writing the book, but also seen as someone who pandered to publicity.<ref>Schmalz, Jeffrey. "At Home With: Randy Shilts; Writing Against Time, Valiantly;" ''New York Times'' April 22, 1993. p. C1.</ref>
Shilts declared while promoting the book in Australia in 1988 that AIDS in the western world could be eradicated, and by 1994, "AIDS could be as manageable as [[diabetes]]". However, in reference to Africa, Shilts noted, "At this point it's inconceivable that there will be an AIDS-free world in Central Africa, as we're looking at a death rate on the scale of the Holocaust."<ref>"West 'AIDS-free within 30 years.'" ''Sunday Mail'' (South Africa), September 4, 1988.</ref> Shilts gave an interview in 1991 where he noticed, "the stellar AIDS reporters in the early years...the people who did the best job—and the reporters who wanted to cover AIDS but their male editors wouldn't let them—tended to be women", and made a connection that if more women were allowed to write about the epidemic, media coverage would have been vastly different.<ref>Shaw, David. "Gender of Editors Affects Coverage of Stories on Sex Media: Women tend to favor more candor in reports on rape, AIDS and the private lives of politicians. Series: THE PRESS AND SEX: Assessing media's coverage when private matters become public. Second in a two-part series." ''Los Angeles Times'': August 19, 1991. p. 1</ref>
Shilts died from complications of AIDS in 1994, age 42.<ref name="lrb"/> Upon his death he was eulogized by [[Cleve Jones]], who said "Randy's contribution was so crucial. He broke through society's denial and was absolutely critical to communicating the reality of AIDS."<ref>Warren, Jennifer. "Randy Shilts, Chronicler of AIDS Epidemic, Dies at 42 Journalism: Author of 'And the Band Played On' is credited with awakening nation to the health crisis."'' Los Angeles Times'' February 18, 1994. p. 1</ref> Larry Kramer said of him, "He single-handedly probably did more to educate the world about AIDS than any single person."<ref>"Randy Shilts, journalist, 42, of AIDS." ''Telegram & Gazette''. (Worcester, Massachusetts): February 18, 1994. p. B.7</ref>
==Film== {{main article|And the Band Played On (film)}}
''And the Band Played On'' was used as the basis for a 1993 [[Primetime Emmy Award]]-winning [[HBO]] [[television film]] of the same name. It was produced by [[Aaron Spelling]], directed by [[Roger Spottiswoode]], and starred [[Matthew Modine]] as epidemiologist [[Don Francis]] and [[Richard Masur]] as [[William Darrow]] at the Centers for Disease Control. [[Alan Alda]] portrayed controversial viral researcher Robert Gallo, and many other stars appeared in supporting and cameo roles, who agreed to appear in the film for [[Screen Actors Guild|union-scale]] pay. The film was released the same year as ''[[Philadelphia (film)|Philadelphia]]'', and the play ''[[Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes]]'' premiered, which prompted one reviewer to note it a triumph and a loss: 12 years after the epidemic had begun, such works of art were necessary still to draw attention to it.<ref>Brelsauer, Jan "1993 year in Review AIDS The Year the Plague Went Mainstream." Los Angeles Times; December 26, 1993. p. 5</ref> Reviews of the film were mixed, claiming that it was a noble try, but failed to be comprehensive enough to cover all the intricacies of the response to AIDS.<ref>Roush, Matt. "'Band': Noble, but slightly out of sync." ''USA TODAY'', September 10, 1993.</ref> However, ''And the Band Played On'', along with other well-received films at the time, was noted for raising the standards of HBO-produced films.<ref>Natale, Richard. "HBO filmmaker gives TV movies a new image." ''The Washington Times'', May 1, 1994, p. D1.</ref>
==See also== * [[Timeline of early HIV/AIDS cases]] * ''[[Zero Patience]]'' (1993 Canadian musical film) * ''[[Sexual Ecology]]'': AIDS and the Destiny of Gay Men (1997 non-fiction book) * ''[[The Hot Zone]]'': A Terrifying True Story (1994 best-selling non-fiction thriller)

{{italic title}} {{About|a statue and a style of grave statuary|the Doctor Who villains|Weeping Angel}} [[Image:WWStoryRome.jpg|thumb|The original ''Angel of Grief'' in Rome]] [[Image:Emelyn Story Tomba (Cimitero Acattolico Roma).jpg|thumb|Other view]] [[File:Angel of Grief at Stanford University profile view.JPG|thumb|Henry Lathrop monument, profile view, at Stanford University]] '''''Angel of Grief''''' or the '''''Weeping Angel''''' is an 1894 sculpture by [[William Wetmore Story]] for the grave of his wife Emelyn Story at the [[Protestant Cemetery, Rome|Protestant Cemetery]] in Rome. Its full title bestowed by the creator was ''The Angel of Grief Weeping Over the Dismantled Altar of Life''.{{cite web|url=https://news.stanford.edu/2015/08/14/vandalism-angel-grief-081415/|title=Stanford police seek information on vandalism of Angel of Grief|date=14 August 2015|work=Stanford News}} This was Story's last major work prior to his death, a year after his wife. The statue's creation was documented in an 1896 issue of ''Cosmopolitan Magazine'': according to this account, his wife's death so devastated Story that he lost interest in sculpture, but was inspired to create the monument by his children, who recommended it as a means of memorializing the woman.''Cosmopolitan Magazine'', cited in {{cite web|url=http://www.hinghamcemetery.org/pie_3f.html|publisher=Hingham Cemetery|title=Angel of Grief|accessdate=10 November 2017}} Unlike the typical angelic grave art, "this dramatic life-size winged figure speaks more of the pain of those left behind" by appearing "collapsed, weeping and draped over the tomb". The term is now used to describe multiple grave stones throughout the world erected in the style of the Story stone.{{cite book|page=158|isbn=9781603441636|title=Houston's Silent Garden|author=Turner, Suzanne; Wilson, Joanne|publisher=Texas A&M Press|year=2010}} A feature in ''[[The Guardian]]'' called the design "one of the most copied images in the world".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/gallery/2013/mar/02/the-10-best-famous-graves|newspaper=The Guardian|title=The 10 best... famous graves|author=Stanford, Peter|date=2 March 2013}} Story himself wrote that "It represents the angel of Grief, in utter abandonment, throwing herself with drooping wings and hidden face over a funeral altar. It represents what I feel. It represents Prostration. Yet to do it helps me."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=FPpqCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT347|title=William Wetmore Story and His Friends|edition=abridged and annotated|author=James, Henry|publisher=Big Byte Books|year=2015}} Prominent replicas of the Angel of Grief sculpture include the Henry Lathrop monument, located in the Stanford Arboretum at [[Stanford University]]. Lathrop was the brother of [[Jane Stanford]], the co-founder of the university. The original replica was built in 1901, but was severely damaged in the [[San Francisco earthquake of 1906]], leading to its replacement in 1908. After years of neglect, the 1908 replacement was fully restored in 2001.{{cite web| title =Labor of Love Leads to a Happy Ending for "Angel of Grief"| url =http://news.stanford.edu/news/2001/april18/mausoleum-418.html| accessdate = 10 May 2010|work=Stanford News}}{{cite web| title =Angel of Grief Restoration| url =http://www.customstonecarving.com/stone%20restoration/Angel%20of%20Grief%20.pdf| accessdate = 10 May 2010}}{{cite web| title =A photo of the Memorial after the 1906 quake, showing the fallen canopy.| url =http://quake06.stanford.edu/centennial/gallery/structures/palmdrive/pages/sc206_bx1_fldr9_pg10.html}} Another example is the Cassard angel, erected around 1908 in the [[Green-Wood Cemetery]] in [[Brooklyn]], New York.{{cite book|page=41|isbn=9781423621027|title= Stories in Stone New York: A Field Guide to New York City Area Cemeteries and Their Residents|author=Keister, Douglas|publisher=Gibbs Smith|year=2011}} The image has also been used in popular culture, such as in an album cover for the band [[Nightwish]]'s album ''[[Once (Nightwish album)|Once]]'' (2004) and in the 2012 film ''[[The Woman in Black]]''. ==Images== Image:Angel of Grief - IN.jpg|[[Holy Sepulchre Cemetery (Rochester, New York)|Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Rochester, New York]] Image:Angel of grief - York PA.jpg|A loose interpretation in York, Pennsylvania Image:DespondentAngelMetCemHead.jpg|[[Chapman H. Hyams|Hyams]] Monument, [[Metairie Cemetery]], New Orleans Image:Teasdale.jpeg|Teasdale Monument, [[Columbus, Mississippi]]. Image:Angel ofGrief - MA.jpg|Hooper Memorial (1912), [[Old Ship Church]], Hingham, Massachusetts Image:GlenwoodAngelofGrief.jpg|Hill Monument,
[[Glenwood Cemetery (Houston, Texas)]] Image:Angel of Grief Lathrop.jpg|Lathrop Memorial,
[[Stanford University]],
[[Palo Alto, California]] Image:Angel of Grief Pool.jpg|[[Jennie Roosevelt Pool|Pool]] Monument,
[[Cypress Lawn Memorial Park]], [[Colma, California]] Image:Eissler monument, Prairie Lea Cemetery, Brenham, Texas.jpg|Eissler Monument, [[Prairie Lea Cemetery]], [[Brenham, Texas]]. This variation has long flowing hair. Image:Angel of Grief, Gloria Cheng, Glenwood Cemetery, Houston, TX.jpg|Gloria Cheng Monument, Glenwood Cemetery, [[Houston, TX]] File:Angel of Grief, modern commercial version.jpg|Commercial version, c. 2016 {{commonscat|Angel of Grief (sculpture)}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *Bliss, Harry A., ''Memorial Art, Ancient and Modern'', Harry A Bliss, Monument Photographer, Buffalo N.Y., 1912 p176 *Brown, John Gary, ''Soul in the Stone: Cemetery Art From America's Heartland'', University of Kansas Press, Lawrence, Kansas, 1994 *Culbertson Randall, ''Permanent Californians: An Illustrated Guide to the Cemeteries of California'', Chelsea Green Publishing Company, Chelsea Vermont, 1989 *Christovich, Huber, McDowell, photographs by Betsy Swanson, ''New Orleans Architecture, Volume lll: the Cemeteries'', Pelican Publishing Co., Gretna, 1997 *Gillon, Edmond V., ''Victorian Cemetery Art'', Dover Publications Inc., New York, 1972 *Kvaran, Einar Einarsson, ''America's Cemetery Sculpture'', unpublished manuscript *Richman, Jeff, author of ''Brooklyn’s Green-Wood Cemetery New York’s Buried Treasure'', phone interview with E. E. Kvaran, September 2006 {{coord|41.876072|12.479535|format=dms|display=title|type:landmark}} [[Category:1894 sculptures]] [[Category:Cemetery art]] [[Category:Grief]] [[Category:Death in art]] [[Category:Stanford University places]] [[Category:Sculptures in the United States]] [[Category:Sculptures of angels]]

{{Coord|45|25|21.84|N|075|41|31.68|W|type:landmark|display=Animals in War Memorial}} {{Infobox military memorial |name=Animals in War Memorial |country=[[Canada]] |image=Animal Memorial2.jpg |caption=Memorial Statue of a dog, from the "Ottawa War" |commemorates=animals used by the Canadian military ([[Canadian Army]]) in conflicts since the [[Second Boer War]] |unveiled=November 3, 2012 |coordinates=[[Confederation Park]] |nearest_town=[[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]] [[Canada]] |designer=[[David Clendining]] |inscription= }} The '''Animals in War Memorial''' (officially '''Animals in War''' and '''Les animaux en temps de guerre''') is a memorial sculpture located at [[Confederation Park]] in [[Ottawa]]. It commemorates animals used by the Canadian military ([[Canadian Army]]) in conflicts since the [[Second Boer War]] (this excludes the use of animals by [[British Army]] and [[French Army]] before [[Canada]] existed as a country).
== Sculptures ==
The memorial consists of three plaques mounted on a stone and sculpture of a dog with foot prints locate next to the [[South African War Memorial, Ottawa]] and near the [[National Aboriginal Veterans Monument]]. The plaques consists of:
* Dedication to animals at war * Dedication to [[Mule]]s * Dedication to [[Horse]]s * Dedication to [[Dog]]s
Inscriptions on the plaques are in English and French.
The plaques and sculpture are created by Ottawa-based artist [[David Clendining]]<ref>http://aiwdedication.ca/aiw-dedication/david-clendining/</ref> with [[Laureen Harper]] as honorary patron of the project.
== Construction ==
The memorial was inspired by [[Lloyd Swick]], a [[World War II]] and [[Korean War]] veteran, who remembered a painting of a horse at war at his high school in 1939. Swick and supporters presented the idea for a memorial to the National Capital Commission Committee in 2010. The memorial became reality and was unveiled on November 3, 2012.<ref>http://aiwdedication.ca/project-history/</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Canadian Armed Forces|Ottawa}}
*[[Animals in War Memorial]], a larger memorial located in [[London]] and unveiled in 2004
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.aiwdedication.ca]
